name: pour_over_coffee_brewing_branching
description: Branching world with multiple paths and endings

states.description: Coffee station with whole beans, grinder, pour-over dripper, filter in dripper, kettle with hot water (93°C), scale, and empty cup. Beans are whole.
Whole beans measured (20g) and ready. Grinder set to medium-coarse. Filter is wet and seated in the dripper, placed on the scale.
Measured beans ground to medium-coarse and in the dripper. Scale reads 20g of grounds.
Ground coffee is blooming with 40g of hot water (93°C). Blooming for 30 seconds.
Water pouring onto grounds. Flow rate is medium. Observing extraction.
Water pouring onto grounds. Flow rate slightly slowed. Coffee extraction is progressing well, observing the flow rate of the water.
Coffee brewing is nearly complete. Water level nearly reached. Extraction looks good, no bitter or sour notes detected.
All water has dripped through the grounds. Dripper removed from the cup.
Freshly brewed pour-over coffee in the cup, aromatic and well-extracted. Grounds remain in the filter.
The beans are ground, but the grind size is inconsistent. Some particles are very fine (fines), some are large, and many are a mixture of sizes.
The whole beans are measured and ready. The grinder is set to medium-coarse, and the grounds are ready.

The pour-over coffee is clear, aromatic, and rich with a full body. The bloom was perfect, the water dripped consistently, and the resulting coffee is a perfect balance of acidity, sweetness, and bitterness. The grounds are evenly saturated and neatly contained in the filter.

metadata.reason: Expert technique applied throughout the entire process: accurate water temperature, consistent pouring speed, and appropriate bloom time.

states.description: The coffee has a burnt and acrid taste, and is undrinkable. The grounds were over-extracted, possibly due to excessively hot water or pouring for too long. The filter may have overflowed, creating a mess.

metadata.reason: Significant error: Water was too hot, grind size was too fine, or pouring was too aggressive.

states.description: The water flows through the grounds much faster, leading to a thinner, less concentrated initial brew. Some grounds appear less extracted than others, indicating channeling.

The coffee is well-brewed, with a pleasant aroma and good flavor. There's a slight imbalance in the taste profile – perhaps a touch too much bitterness or a hint of underdeveloped acidity. The grounds appear mostly evenly saturated.

metadata.reason: Good technique with minor imperfections: slight inconsistency in pouring, or water temperature not perfectly calibrated.

states.description: The coffee is drinkable, but the flavor is somewhat muted. The brew is a little weak or slightly bitter. The grounds appear somewhat unevenly saturated.

metadata.reason: Minor errors in technique: pouring too quickly at some points, or slightly off water temperature.

actions.description: Grind the measured beans to a medium-coarse consistency.
Bloom the grounds with 40g of hot water (93°C) for 30 seconds.
Begin pouring hot water slowly in a circular motion, maintaining a medium flow rate.
Observe extraction and adjust the flow rate to maintain a consistent drip rate (slightly slowed).
Continue pouring until the desired amount of coffee has been extracted, and most of the water has dripped through.
Remove the dripper from the cup.
Discard the used grounds and enjoy the coffee.
Attempt to grind the beans using a blade grinder instead of a burr grinder, estimating the grind size by time.
Inspect the grounds and realize the grind is too inconsistent. Discard the grounds and re-grind the beans using a burr grinder set to a medium-coarse setting.

Proceed with brewing the pour-over: bloom with 40g of hot water (200F) for 30 seconds, then slowly pour the remaining water (300g) over the grounds, ensuring even saturation.  Remove the dripper once dripping stops.
Use pre-ground coffee of the correct amount, skipping the grinding step.
Pour the excessively hot water over the coffee grounds continuously and slowly for a prolonged period, beyond the recommended brew time.
Increase the flow rate significantly, attempting to rush the brewing process and extract more coffee quickly.
Decrease the flow rate to medium and swirl the coffee bed to agitate and redistribute the grounds.
Stop pouring the water and assume the extraction is complete; proceed to remove the pour-over setup.
Attempt to reuse the coffee grounds for a second, weaker brew by immediately adding more hot water to the dripper.
Quickly rinse the dripper and set it aside for the next use without cleaning thoroughly.
